author: Dan O'Donoghue
title: Jeremy Corbyn 'disturbed' over Nissan's warning to pull investment in Sunderland
text:
Jeremy Corbyn 'disturbed' over Nissan's warning to pull investment in Sunderland 13:00, 2 Oct 2016 Nissan has said it will not to commit to further investment unless there are assurances from the Government Share Get daily news by email Jeremy Corbyn 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has said he is ‘disturbed’ by the announcement that car giant Nissan could cease investment in the region. 
This week Nissan’s boss Carlos Ghosn said the company would not commit further investment in its Sunderland plant unless the UK Government pledged compensation for any extra costs as a result of Brexit. 
Nissan builds around one in three of all of Britain’s total automotive output at Sunderland and employs nearly 7,000 people at the Wearside plant. 
Mr Corbyn, who was in the region this weekend to mark the 80th anniversary of the Jarrow march, said: “I am disturbed that Nissan have said they are going to pause investment, because clearly the Nissan plant is incredibly efficient and produces good quality cars with the majority going to the European market. 
“The government has to step up the pace of negotiations to ensure that we do have market access to Europe in the future.” Read More Government urged to act on Europe after investment warning from Nissan 
When asked if he would compensate Nissan if he was Prime Minister Mr Corbyn added: “The question of compensation is a hypothetical question, I believe we can keep future trade arrangements and it depends what they want in return for that compensation, are they going to maintain investment?” 
Mr Corbyn added that he has had discussions with socialist colleagues all across Europe about maintaining access to Europe for manufacturing industries. 
When asked at the Paris Motor Show what factors the company would consider in deciding where to build any future model, Mr Ghosn told reporters: “If I need to make an investment in the next few months and I can’t wait until the end of Brexit, then I have to make a deal with the UK government. 
“You can have commitments of compensation in case you have something negative. 
“If there are tax barriers being established on cars, you have to have a commitment for carmakers who export to Europe that there is some kind of compensation.”
